options: Copies a repository to your local machine
explanation:
`git clone` **copies a remote repository** to your local machine, including all history and branches.

```bash
# Clone a repository
git clone https://github.com/user/repo.git

# Clone into specific directory
git clone https://github.com/user/repo.git my-folder

# Clone specific branch
git clone -b develop https://github.com/user/repo.git

# Shallow clone (only recent history)
git clone --depth 1 https://github.com/user/repo.git
```

questionText: What is the difference between 'git pull' and 'git fetch'?
options: pull fetches and merges, fetch only downloads
fetch fetches and merges, pull only downloads
explanation:
`git pull` = `git fetch` + `git merge`. **fetch** downloads changes, **pull** downloads and merges.

```bash
# git fetch - downloads changes but doesn't merge
git fetch origin
git log origin/main  # View changes
git merge origin/main  # Merge when ready

# git pull - downloads and merges immediately
git pull origin main
# Equivalent to:
git fetch origin
git merge origin/main

# Pull with rebase instead of merge
git pull --rebase origin main
```

`git status` shows the **current branch** and **state of files** (modified, staged, untracked).

```bash
git status

# Output shows:
# - Current branch
# - Changes staged for commit (green)
# - Changes not staged (red)
# - Untracked files
# - Branch sync status with remote

# Short format
git status -s
# M  modified.txt    (staged)
#  M unstaged.txt    (modified, not staged)
# ?? untracked.txt  (untracked)
```

questionText: What is the difference between 'git reset' and 'git revert'?
options: reset rewrites history, revert creates new commit
revert rewrites history, reset creates new commit
explanation:
`git reset` **rewrites history** (dangerous for shared branches), `git revert` **creates a new commit** that undoes changes (safe).

```bash
# git reset - rewrites history
git reset --soft HEAD~1   # Undo commit, keep changes staged
git reset --mixed HEAD~1  # Undo commit, unstage changes (default)
git reset --hard HEAD~1   # Undo commit, discard changes

# git revert - creates new commit
git revert HEAD           # Create new commit undoing last commit
git revert abc123         # Revert specific commit

# When to use:
# - reset: local commits not pushed yet
# - revert: commits already pushed to shared branch
```

options: Adds all files in current directory to staging
explanation:
`git add .` **stages all changes** in the current directory and subdirectories.

```bash
# Add all changes in current directory
git add .

# Add specific file
git add file.txt

# Add all files (including deleted)
git add -A
# or
git add --all

# Add by pattern
git add *.js

# Interactive staging
git add -p  # Choose which changes to stage
```

`git stash` **temporarily saves changes** so you can work on something else, then reapply them later.

```bash
# Save current changes
git stash
# or with message
git stash save "WIP: feature X"

# List stashes
git stash list
# stash@{0}: WIP: feature X
# stash@{1}: On main: bug fix

# Apply most recent stash
git stash apply

# Apply and remove from stash list
git stash pop

# Apply specific stash
git stash apply stash@{1}

# Delete stash
git stash drop stash@{0}

# Clear all stashes
git stash clear
```

options: Creates a commit with a message
explanation:
`git commit -m` **creates a commit** with the specified message.

```bash
# Commit with message
git commit -m "Add login feature"

# Commit all tracked changes (skip git add)
git commit -am "Fix bug"

# Amend last commit
git commit --amend -m "Updated message"

# Commit with detailed message
git commit -m "Add feature" -m "Detailed description here"

# Empty commit (for CI triggers)
git commit --allow-empty -m "Trigger build"
```

options: Rewrites commit history by moving commits
explanation:
`git rebase` **rewrites history** by moving commits to a new base, creating a linear history.

```bash
# Rebase current branch onto main
git rebase main

# Interactive rebase (edit last 3 commits)
git rebase -i HEAD~3
# Options: pick, reword, edit, squash, fixup, drop

# Rebase vs Merge:
# Merge: creates merge commit, preserves history
git merge feature

# Rebase: linear history, no merge commit
git rebase main

# ⚠️ Never rebase commits pushed to shared branches!
```

`git branch` **lists, creates, or deletes branches**.

```bash
# List all local branches
git branch

# List all branches (including remote)
git branch -a

# Create new branch
git branch feature-x

# Delete branch
git branch -d feature-x   # Safe delete (merged only)
git branch -D feature-x   # Force delete

# Rename branch
git branch -m old-name new-name

# Show current branch
git branch --show-current
```

options: Applies specific commit to current branch
explanation:
`git cherry-pick` **applies a specific commit** from another branch to your current branch.

```bash
# Cherry-pick single commit
git cherry-pick abc123

# Cherry-pick multiple commits
git cherry-pick abc123 def456

# Cherry-pick range
git cherry-pick abc123..def456

# Cherry-pick without committing
git cherry-pick -n abc123

# Use case: apply hotfix from main to release branch
git checkout release
git cherry-pick hotfix-commit-hash
```

options: Shows reference log of HEAD movements
explanation:
`git reflog` shows **history of HEAD movements**, useful for recovering lost commits.

```bash
# View reflog
git reflog

# Recover lost commit after reset
git reset --hard HEAD~3  # Oops, lost commits!
git reflog  # Find commit hash
git reset --hard abc123  # Recover

# Recover deleted branch
git branch -D feature  # Oops!
git reflog  # Find last commit on feature
git checkout -b feature abc123  # Recreate

# Reflog expires after 90 days by default
```

`git log` shows **commit history** with author, date, and message.

```bash
# Basic log
git log

# One line per commit
git log --oneline

# Show last 5 commits
git log -5

# Show commits with file changes
git log --stat

# Show commits with diff
git log -p

# Graph view
git log --graph --oneline --all

# Filter by author
git log --author="John"

# Filter by date
git log --since="2 weeks ago"
```

`git merge --squash` **combines all commits** from a branch into a single commit.

```bash
# Regular merge (keeps all commits)
git merge feature
# Creates merge commit with all feature commits

# Squash merge (single commit)
git merge --squash feature
git commit -m "Add feature X"
# All changes in one commit, cleaner history

# Use case: feature branch with many WIP commits
# Result: clean main branch history
```

options: Binary search to find bug-introducing commit
explanation:
`git bisect` uses **binary search** to find which commit introduced a bug.

```bash
# Start bisect
git bisect start

# Mark current commit as bad
git bisect bad

# Mark known good commit
git bisect good abc123

# Git checks out middle commit
# Test it, then mark:
git bisect good  # or
git bisect bad

# Repeat until found
# Git will identify the first bad commit

# End bisect
git bisect reset

# Automated bisect
git bisect run npm test
```

questionText: What is the difference between 'git merge' and 'git rebase'?
options: merge preserves history, rebase creates linear history
rebase preserves history, merge creates linear history
explanation:
`git merge` **preserves history** with merge commits, `git rebase` **rewrites history** for linear commits.

```bash
# Merge - preserves branch history
git checkout main
git merge feature
# Creates merge commit, shows branch existed

# Rebase - linear history
git checkout feature
git rebase main
# Moves feature commits on top of main
# No merge commit, cleaner history

# When to use:
# Merge: public/shared branches, preserve history
# Rebase: local branches, clean history

# ⚠️ Golden rule: Never rebase public branches!
```
